specs/stein/approved/glance/spec-lite-re.message: Extra white space in a few places in this file.
We should also make sure that those 2 stores are excluded from any listings (doscoverability) and not accepted as stores in the image calls.

To facilitate this, and make it extensible, I suggest we name these os_glance_tasks_store and os_glance_staging_store and document that the 'os_glance_' prefix is reserved for glance and cannot be used by operators to name their stores.
I'm a bit worried that this will make configuring backends a bit cumbersome.  I wonder whether it would better to have a separate option, 'system_backends' where these would be defined?

I'd personally just not list them (apart from the help text) if possible and definitely not have yet another separate useless config option cluttering our configs. Needing to have them in the list just gives opportunity to have a typo or something wonky in there we have not even thought about potentially causing more issues.
So instead of defining them in conf, we should inject them when service starts and make a note about same right?
I think that would solve the confusion for now.

Agree, my main concern is not listing them in this list of backends, since this list is the backends the operator wants to expose to end users.  I suggested the system_backends so that we'd have the <backend_name>:<backend_type> in the list in case we want eventually to support backend_types other than file.  Is there another way we can determine the backend type for the staging area and task scratch dir?

What we could do, for now, is to keep them hardcoded apart from the path configuration and just inject them onto the list upon start and document them in the help text as reserved backend IDs for internal use. I know it's not the most elegant way of doing things, but it would keep them under control until we have made sure this approach works and can expand it to other possible backends.

kuryr_kubernetes/cni/binding/sriov.py.message: Maybe just check vf_sys_path existence and do not handle logic in exception handling block, just for readability.
So we can handle it with if else here and raise exception. Or introduce local helper function for it, which will return correct vf_name or throw an exception.

I agree, it would be more readable, but if vf_sys_path does not exist it means the it was binded on userspace driver and there are two ways of actions:

1. If we want to rebind this device on some userspace driver, we do not need it's vf_name, so we can set it in None and do not throw an exception.

2. If we want to rebind this device on some kernel driver, we need it's vf_name, but it doesn't exist. It tells about misconfiguration (between sriov-device-plugin and kuryr-kubernetes) and we should throw an exception

Agreed. Tagging x86_64 won't break anything...
IMHO it should be just
arch_tag: "{{ ansible_architecture }}"

you might wonder why we're not tagging all containers with the format {{ version_hash }}_{{ ansible_architecture }} here and then retag x86_64 with {{ version_hash }} later on.

The intent is to prioritize tags. It is more important for x86_64 tags to maintain their compatibility with current consumers than it is for them to have a tag of the same format as other arches.

The containers are tagged with their "most important" tag first, so that if push succeeds, it is guaranteed that the most important tag can be used.

It may be a small gain, but I think it's worth the added complexity.
so add a brief 2/line comment above this saying that ^ "push 'old' style no arch first for backwards compat"

every time we've explored this retag, i've had the same thought. This has the advantage of querying the registry (right?) so we confirm stuff uploaded OK. BUT its also expensive and prone to network issues etc. We could try and retrieve the list from the list of containers we just built e.g. in the build.log

really the answer is 'whatever is easiest to land first' .. if that podman images query works ok for you then just do that

This is a fair concern.

I went with it as it's an implementation that's been used in the past. Also, it gets you a confirmation that the initial push happened with the desired tag, and fails otherwise.

For now I'm keeping this implementation but I am open to using something else if more people agree.

guidelines/api-schema.rst.message:
typo: with

Also it's unclear what you mean by "provided by each project". is it your desired state? because it's pretty clear that not all projects provide schemas.
Yes that's what I mean, let me rephrase
I cannot find a single mention of the word "schema" in this document. Do you mean a human-readable explanation? If so, it's not trivial to use from tools
That's right there is not mention of API schema but the OpenAPI/swagger is mentioned. Which is not obvious is the fact that the API schema tree is used for the documentation.

Oh, I'm starting to get what you mean :) Let's begin this document with the definition of "schema" within it. I was imagining something like a JSON schema.

And my previous point holds valid: I'm not sure every project publishes an api-ref. ironic-inspector does not for sure. We may be able to talk about "the majority", I guess.

Well I believe a formal API schema tree has to be defined in a some sort of format like JSON or YAML, the current format is RST and the definition is informal.

All projects under api-guide (ex api-ref) use the same guidelines in order to produce a consistent reference:  

https://developer.openstack.org/api-guide/quick-start/

So yes that's the majority and the missing ones to be rallied anyway.
typo: Objective
Done
Mmmm, is it objective of this guideline? Like, are you proposing a tool to convert RST to JSON schema (for example) or is this guideline about consuming the RST "schema" directly?

Actually sphinx is to generate the schema since it's already in memory, that would be less disruptive from the current process.

Since that has been clarified at last weekly meeting I'll update the document accordingly.

you might consider emphasizing this point a bit more by moving a version of it into the intro. The document needs to explain, early on, why we need the automation you're suggesting, and this is the compelling point.
Done

Another merit is easy to measure API coverage on integration tests from QA viewpoint.
For example, Kubernetes provides OpenAPI spec data and I created the measuring tool for its integration test.

https://github.com/kubernetes/test-infra/tree/master/experiment/coverage
Updated document accordingly
Thanks! That sound like music to me. I'll add this to document as well as updates after we brain storm the below comments a bit more.

I am confused what is difference between this "API schema" and OpenAPI. If this is OpenAPI itself, please use OpenAPI instead of a new definition.

My following comment is based on OpenAPI.
I have updated the document, where I refer to outside link about API DL comparisons. I'm not sure this document is where such vote should take place (but why not if there is no other choice).

> But before even considering any API standard, we need to
 > have a normalized API schema. Although there are no
 > official API schema defined within the community, the
 > common practice has created a "de-facto" API schema model
 > which is informal. So we need to formalize that first.

OK, how about changing this spec like

 Definition of API schema
 ------------------------
 ...


 Requirements of API schema
 --------------------------
 ...


 Candidates of API schema
 ------------------------
 OpenAPI (aka Swagger)
 - Pros
   ...
 - Cons
   ...
 JSON-Home
 - Pros
   ...
 - Cons
   ...
 foo
   ...

You're touching the most 'sensitive' part here!

At the moment OpenStack APIs are not supporting any API standard. OpenAPI (ex swagger) was the closest candidate but the main blocker is because Microversion is not supported by OpenAPI.

But before even considering any API standard, we need to have a normalized API schema. Although there are no official API schema defined within the community, the common practice has created a "de-facto" API schema model which is informal. So we need to formalize that first.

Part of the process here is to make sure everyone understand API schema means API standard such as OpenAPI is a good thing. And like many other things in the Open Source world we exist and rely on open standards.  

Also this represents a challenge for the API SIG, to be able to take a top-bottom approach instead of the usual opposite where various projects have been pushing things up, like the microversion. So are the projects going to agree to support API Schema normalization?

I think microversions itself can be solved.
If each service(nova, etc) provides OpenAPI spec data via its REST API, consumers can get the corresponding microversioned data by specifying necessary microversion on a request header.
So we just need to get multiple OpenAPI spec data for all microversions for each service.

Another issue is action APIs which share the same URL and Method(POST, PUT, ..) on multiple APIs with different request body. Basically OpenAPI is based on the scenario the pair of URL and Method is represent as a single API. I cannot find a best way to solve this issue at this time. (It is possible to mix multiple action APIs as a single API data, but that would be mess and confused)
Yes. There is no doubt microversion is not ideal (bad?) for consumers. BTW does anybody care?

> So we just need to get multiple OpenAPI spec data for all microversions for each service.

This is fine, but if we start generating client libraries from that we're going to end up with a completely new client library for each microversion.

That depends on how to implement client libraries.
That means it would be fine to implement a single client library from multiple OpenAPI spec data of multiple microversions.

I don't think that is bad, there are concrete merits actually.
But I agree with that is not ideal with something hard.
It seems like this should be "APIs consumer" or "APIs client", otherwise the sentence is pretty confusing :-)

I think the approach we currently have in sushy-tools is like this:

1) hide the implementation details (such as pulling drives from the map) inside driver (e.g. staticdriver)
2) expose some higher level and universally applicable abstraction across all prospective drivers (e.g. get-me-all-drives)
3) do the linkage (e.g. chassis->drivers) in `main.py` flask view

I don't know if we should be paranoid here about trapping any errors if we're iterating a list of providers from an aggregate, I mean since we just got them above they should exist, but we could race...or it could be large set, e.g. let's say I have a cell of 200 providers in an aggregate that represents the cell and I want to change some allocation ratio on all of them in aggregate, I guess if you're automating things theoretically some other external process could delete one of the providers while you're iterating the list here. Not a huge deal and not something I want to block this on, but could be a follow up hardening opportunity. It would also probably be hard to test that in the functional tests without using some kind of mock.

As usual, I realized what you meant after I asked and re-read my own comment. You were talking about "what if the GET fails". I think we should do a similar "log and continue" thing but agreed it will be potentially complicated to test (how to make a GET fail without mocking -- probably not possible, like you said).

Yeah, a race here is definitely possible. I think we're at least safe from the possibility of accidentally reverting a change made by an external call because of the resource_provider_generation (will fail with a conflict on L194) and then we'll get the aggregate "log and continue" handling. cinderclient/client.py.message:
I think this usage of sha1 is also not a security problem, and changing this to sha256 is actually perhaps worse for what this is doing.

As far as I can tell (with no comments documenting this method), this is used to generate output when debugging things at the CLI that masks headers that shouldn't be printed (auth tokens), but in a way that lets you see that the same header shows up more than once.  Changing from sha1 to 256 means it's longer and harder to read/compare in the logs.

This looks like:
    DEBUG:keystoneauth:REQ: curl -g -i -X GET http://10.16.151.37/volume/ -H "Accept: application/json" -H "OpenStack-API-Version: volume 3.58" -H "User-Agent: python-cinderclient" -H "X-Auth-Token: {SHA256}135bb5d2ea78c3466d6222654185c5de2dac832e4d46c79e5ebbcfd081d3eb67"

(Which is kind of funny because the whole point of logging it as a "curl" command is that you could copy/paste it and run it, which clearly won't work if the token is masked this way...)

But -- where does SHA1 show up currently, anyway?  I'm not running this patch and I already see SHA256 instead of SHA1 for headers (above).

I think we need to thoroughly understand what this code does and document it before just changing it to make bandit happy.
The answer for why I see the SHA256 masking is presumably because my "normal" CLI usage is using the session client and not HTTPClient.
